repnme.cdata!: Mexico - Renewable Energy for Agriculture Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Mexico renewable energy for
            agriculture project were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: In order to ensure the optimal impact of
            interventions, it was essential that the principal project
            implementing agency was related to the agriculture sector in
            order that it could promote productive uses of the energy.
            In order to ensure the optimal impact of interventions, it
            became clear during implementation that it was essential to
            consider the livelihood consequences that will occur through
            provision of renewable energy and to integrate this into all
            components, including through investing in improving
            productive processes. It is important to ensure that
            dissemination is considered carefully in project design.
            Subprojects must be supported by co-financing from
            beneficiaries. For renewable energy investments to have a
            high impact and broad replication, an effective financing
            scheme is very important and this will most likely have to
            involve subsidized financing. Close monitoring and tracking
            of technical assistance and its results through innovative
            use of the internet and GIS can help greatly to evaluate the
            success of activities and to modify and optimize them.

5086823.trustfund:
TF023251-GEF FSP - MEXICO RENEWABLE

5086823.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!: Mexico - Renewable Energy for Agriculture Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Renewable Energy for Agriculture
            Project will provide electricity supply in rural areas for
            productive purposes, in a sustainable manner, through
            renewable energy technologies. It will support productive
            investments, and improved farming practices, and will
            further improve the ability of the Trust Fund for Shared
            Risk (FIRCO), in the transformation of those technologies,
            for the benefit of the agriculture sector. The components
            include: a) a promotion campaign targeting renewable energy
            for agricultural productive purposes, and, training to
            technicians, agricultural extension experts, and energy
            system vendors, will be provided. Technical specifications
            and certification procedures will be introduced for
            farm-based energy equipment, and market studies will focus
            on the potential for agricultural applications; b)
            installation of solar and wind-powered water pumping
            systems, and solar-powered refrigerated milk storage tanks,
            for participating farmers as demonstration units; c)
            technical assistance, which will be provided by renewable
            energy-trained agricultural extension experts, to advise
            farmers on the new energy operation procedures; d) a pilot
            program will test innovative vendor financing mechanisms for
            farm-based energy systems in four states; and, e) project
            management will be implemented and coordinated by FIRCO.
